name: NewYorker
text: “Homegrown”—technically Neil Young’s 40th album but recorded more than 45 years ago—features some extraordinary guest players and is suffused with a kind of loose, creaky ease.  https://t.co/Rf79TL02og

name: NewYorker
text:
Who has the standing to legally challenge Donald Trump’s deployment of D.H.S. troops in Portland? An expert weighs in.
https://t.co/ucRGL1GXR0

name: NewYorker
text:
How the songs in Pop Smoke's posthumous album became rallying cries for protestors—a tribute to those who have died unjustly.
https://t.co/hWySdKSrs8

name: NewYorker
text: Donald Trump is delusional about what his powers are—they do not include simply declaring that there is a cure for COVID-19—but the powers of the Presidency are substantial, and he can do a great deal of harm, @tnyCloseRead writes. https://t.co/P1Qj0C8zYu

name: NewYorker
text: “We cannot just ignore it when the President threatens to cancel an election,” @sbg1 writes. “This is the kind of statement that should haunt your dreams. It is wannabe-dictator talk.” https://t.co/uz0h62N6rb

name: NewYorker
text: Frustrated that literary history entrusted the story of America’s first Black poet to a white woman, the poet and professor Honorée Fanonne Jeffers spent years hunting through archives—and finding a different story. https://t.co/T0DOvHmVUv

name: NewYorker
text: We would do well to remember that queer people considered themselves married long before the state sanctioned it, @jimdowns1 writes. https://t.co/Z7jVQP4zuf

name: NewYorker
text:
.@etammykim on the history of the term "people of color," and whether it is still useful during the recent uprising for Black lives, when the literal and figurative terms of cross-race solidarity have come into extreme flux.
https://t.co/gLVPg0b2Fh

name: NewYorker
text:
"For those who can take a stolen moment of repose, the Nap Dress has a tranquillizing allure," @rachsyme writes. "It is a clean slate, white noise, a gauzy, brief escape for those who can afford it."
https://t.co/Pc2F5vQ3xl

name: NewYorker
text: A conversation with @thomaschattwill, on why he thinks cancel culture has a "narrowing" and "stifling" effect on speech and thought. https://t.co/3GKjgp3dy0

text: A throwback to the original "Zoom," one of the most memorable and radically experimental TV programs of the 1970s. https://t.co/Zh4RpJfauc

text: The women of the Combahee River Collective, formed in 1974, imagined a course of politics that could take Black women from the margins of society to the center of a revolution. https://t.co/AlMb2l6ygP

name: NewYorker
text: We should be asking not whether colleges should get their tuition dollars by putting students, faculty, and staff at risk but how to insure that college students will be able to learn in a meaningful way. https://t.co/cFoLMmfhkP

name: NewYorker
text: "I know there is no way to guarantee safety for my baby, who, at 37 weeks, rides in my uterus while I work as a pediatric hospitalist amid the blossoming pandemic in Texas," @HumanitiesMD writes. https://t.co/4Q919YbOZR

name: NewYorker
text: If the first wave of the virus in the Texas Panhandle was a story of rumor, stalled information, and essential work, the second wave was a story of reopening based on willful ignorance. https://t.co/Xukxjqy5hX

name: NewYorker
text: “A sudden hush fell on the crowd as Mr. Summers cleared his throat and looked at the list. ‘All ready?’ he called.” Listen to A. M. Homes read and discuss Shirley Jackson’s classic short story. https://t.co/qiXNfe7Kz3

name: NewYorker
text: “What I found from the 1960s is that nonviolent protest achieved many of the same sorts of outcomes that the more militant activists were fighting for without splintering the Democratic coalition.” An interview with @owasow. https://t.co/la9GRt0jkk

name: NewYorker
text: Any study of the codpiece begins with two simple questions: Why did it exist at all, and why did men elect to wear it? https://t.co/GFIpdLsQH8

name: NewYorker
text:
Tibetans have been spared some of the worst abuses of China’s ethnic policies—namely, the involuntary detentions of up to a million Uighurs—but the Communist Party is ever more intrusive in their lives.
https://t.co/Yh3Lc32LkM

name: NewYorker
text: "For when 'hospice' is spoken, the fact is at last acknowledged: There is no hope." Flash fiction by @JoyceCarolOates. https://t.co/Ybme1W23D7

text: The Republicans who have shrugged off President Trump’s recent statements are failing to protect their constituents from a disease that can be controlled, and they are failing to protect the Constitution, @tnyCloseRead writes. https://t.co/dDGtRci75Z

text: “Look, Mike said. Just because something isn’t working doesn’t mean it’s broken. You just have to want to fix it. The want has to be there.” New fiction by @brywashing. https://t.co/3abNHrXeb7
